On Sun, Apr 14, 2013 at 5:01 PM, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:

> **
>
> Thanks for your comments on our work. I don't mind at all you saying that
> you think Sims creatures are just as natural. I'm actually quite interested
> in hearing the community's opinions on this front, whatever they are. We
> purposefully did not take a stand on whether we have matched/beat Sims.
> Instead, our point was simply that adding the degrees of freedom we did and
> evolving with CPPNs shows promise that may, with future work, enable the
> community to produce organisms that obviously surpass Sims. I definitely
> think we are not "obviously" better yet, which should be a goal of our
> field.
>

Okay, cool. Thanks for the clarification.


>
> Your question about why the creatures are not more regular one is an
> interesting one that I myself have been puzzling over since the beginning
> of this project. I originally expected that we'd get creatures like those
> from EndlessForms.com that walk around. As you point out, though, the
> creatures in this paper are not nearly that symmetric (either bilaterally
> or radially). There is clearly a lot of regularity, especially compared to
> the direct encoding (as Ken points out), but not nearly as much as in
> EndlessForms and Picbreeder. My current leading hypothesis as to why is
> very similar to Ken's, which is why our next step is to repeat the work
> with diversity algorithms like MOLE and NS+LC (novelty search + local
> competition).
>
>
Awesome. Good luck with this work going forward.


> As for when different types of symmetry evolved in nature: a lot of that
> is addressed in Raff's book "The Shape of Life", which Ken recommended to
> me long ago.
>
>
Thanks for the book recommendation. I'll check it out.


> Thanks again for your comments. I look forward to seeing your evolved
> creature work when it comes out.
>
>
I'll definitely post it to the group when I make some headway. My first cut
just involved a static body with 3 parts, a torso and two limbs, each limb
connected with a 6-degree-of-freedom joint. I used NEAT to evolve the
neural network controllers for the joints. I just used a simple fitness
function favoring distance traveled. Even with this simple first pass, in
only 15 generations I was able to get individuals that moved around pretty
well (a sort of breast stroke on solid ground was the most common
strategy). It's pretty satisfying seeing your creations progress from
non-functional to actually doing cool stuff in relatively short periods of
time.

Anyway, congrats again, and good luck on the work!

--Derek

--047d7bdca2a25406d604da6c297e
